Fields.DialogueText: Capitano... There have been Morganas creeping along in our wake for hours now. They're just out of our sight in this weather, but they can't hide their scent.
Sometimes I'm not sure if you're a Belle or a bloodhound. A puppy really was the perfect gift for you.
I was being metaphorical. It's not so much an actual scent, but a... a trail. Something wrong, that has no right to be in the seas.
They reek, but not in a way you or any of the crew - or even my puppy - could understand.
Interesting. Well, if they're following us, it's unlikely their intentions are good. How do you feel about turning and attacking them?
That would be the usual course of action.
And you believe it is the right one?
... Yes, Capitano. Of course!
@BATTLE
Another victory. Good job spotting them, Emanuele.
Grazie.
*WOOF*

Fields.MenuText: I think your puppy is demanding your attention.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh, I think you're right.

Fields.MenuText: Make sure he doesn't chew up the ship.
I'm not going to compete with a puppy for your attention.

Fields.DialogueText: I'd be the first to know if he bit anything important. I'd feel it!
Really?
I think so...
So you'd feel it if I bit something on the ship?
Hahaha! Is that something you're likely to try? I'll admit, I'm a little bit curious now...
You don't have to compete, Capitano. I'm still your Belle, puppy or not.
Oh! Hello, Capitano. Welcome! I was just rearranging my new quarters... How do you like them?
It looks orderly, if a bit sparse. I suppose our work hasn't given you much of an opportunity to collect possessions.
I don't need much. I have everything an alpine girl like me could possibly want, at least on board this ship.
Plus, if I had things lying around, my puppy would just chew them to shreds.
So this is where the portrait of your namesake went. I was wondering why it disappeared from the drawing room.
I know it bothered some of the officers. His participation in the Great War... well, he was a hero, but I know not everyone feels that way about him.
I didn't want to offend or cause discomfort to any of our officers or crew, so I thought it better to move him down here, now that I have space for him.
That's a good thought, Emanuele. ... What's that little box beneath him?
Just another memento, Capitano, of the places I come from and the places I have been.
I've heard some Belles like to collect souvenirs. Do you want me to get you something the next time we make port?
Oh, thank you, Capitano! But no, that's all right. I think I should keep my quarters sparse. Like I said, I don't really need much.
Unless you happen on some books of poetry in my native tongue! Sadly, they're harder to find than they once were.
Forces inside my country have seen to that.

Fields.MenuText: That's a painful thing. I'm sorry.
You're certainly more free with your words now our spy is gone.
There's nothing wrong with the promotion of cultural unity.

Fields.DialogueText: ... It is life, Capitano. It is not my place to make such decisions, or understand why those decisions were made. I will trust in the judgment of my superiors.
... Don't say such things, Capitano. We still must be circumspect. A girl like me cannot fathom the reasons for a thing like Italianization... but I suppose those above me must have them.
Smaller cultures, however, can have tremendous impact on people, and some don't like to see their customs stripped away.
I would love to sit and talk all day, Capitano, but I'm afraid the hunt calls. I sensed Morganas on the prowl.
These ones, at least, are bolder than the last.
We'll be sure to teach them what such boldness will earn them.
@BATTLE
I must have seen your puppy in half a dozen crew members' hands today.
Hah, he's the darling of the whole ship. Even the ship's cat seems to like him.
You're not foisting your responsibilities onto the crew, I trust?
Of course not. I know he is mine to care for, and I make sure he is properly fed and looked after. But some of the crew do like to take him on walks, from time to time.
If you don't approve, I can tell the crew members to ignore him...
Don't look so sad. I was just making sure he wouldn't be a distraction.
Of course not, Capitano. The puppy goes into his kennel in my quarters at the first sign of trouble.
... Though, admittedly, trouble comes more often than I'd like.
Have you given him a name yet?
No, not yet. I'm so unsure about names. The crew has given me a few suggestions, but I don't know if I should let them pick.

Fields.MenuText: You should make the decision yourself. He's your dog, after all.
It seems fine to take suggestions if you're stuck.
Who cares? He's just a dog.

Fields.DialogueText: That's true, Capitano. Naming him is my responsibility. I shouldn't foist it off on others... any more than anything else.
You're right. Some of their suggestions have been interesting. It's strange sometimes to see the mix of cultures on my decks, even now... It's hard to believe I lived so isolated before.
I know. But he's my companion. Names are important.
I'm glad that you're taking your new role as dog owner seriously.
Hah, I take all my roles seriously, Capitano. Especially that of Morgana hunter. I think we have some nearby.
Then let's track them down, shall we?
@BATTLE
I'm looking forward to seeing North America. I don't know those waters well, but I've heard so much about them from the other Belles.
Are your home countries a common point of discussion?
Many of the Belles do like sharing things about their homelands. The American Belles are usually particularly effusive.
You look sad, Emanuele.
What do you think of America, Capitano? Does it live up to all its ideals?

Fields.MenuText: I think it lives up to its ideals as best a country can.
No. It falls short, like all countries.
I've never been to America, so I can't say.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe that's why its Belles believe in it so fiercely. I don't blame them.
Well, some of its Belles certainly believe it to be worth all praise.
Ah, I see. This will be an adventure for both of us, then. We'll see for ourselves whether the American Belles are justified in their praise for their homeland.
I wish... it could be the same for all Belles, of all countries.
Patriotism seems to be a common trait for all Belles. You can't rely on stereotypes of Americans and discount the patriotism of others.
I just know my duty to my king, Capitano, and to you. Not patriotism. It's hard to imagine how such an ideal could drive any Belle.
Does that make me a bad Belle?
Don't answer that. We have more pressing matters. Look ahead, Capitano!
Morganas.
We're prepared for the challenge. For Aosta, and Savoy!
@BATTLE
Look, Capitano! There's the Statue of Liberty! She really can be seen from miles away.
She can be. I didn't realize you would get so excited over landmarks. Think you could climb her?
Hah, maybe, if I wasn't bound to this ship. I wouldn't want to, though. I prefer the monuments nature creates.
Though I've heard she has French origins... so I suppose we have something in common.
Although I suppose I shouldn't speak of such things...
You don't have to lock up every little fact and opinion you have. Mussolini's eyes aren't watching you anymore.
How can I be sure? We rid ourselves of one spy, but there could be many more.

Fields.MenuText: I have faith in my crew. There are no spies among them.
Even if there is another spy, neither the fleet nor I would let you be locked away in drydock for your opinions.
Don't waste your time worrying. Morganas should be your only concern out here.

Fields.DialogueText: ... I have faith in them too. Or... I want to. You're probably right, Capitano. Thank you.
... I believe you. I trust you, Capitano.
... I trust your judgment, Capitano. I'm sorry for being paranoid.
... There are Cattive Ragazze nearby. They're coming close to New York Harbor. I doubt they're hunting us - their target is probably the harbor.
Well, then, it's our duty to defend it.
@BATTLE
There you are, Emanuele.
Ah! Hello, Capitano. Sorry... I must have dozed off.
Nothing to worry about. You and the pup look cozy.
I came down here after our last fight. He had been spooked by something, probably one of the shells that exploded near our deck. It took a while to calm him down... and I must have fallen asleep.
Augh, look at the mess my hair is in...
I can hardly tell any sort of difference.
Still, I prefer to keep my appearance orderly. I think the puppy has been chewing one of my ribbons... Bad dog! Look at how bad you've made me look, and in front of my capitano, no less!

Fields.MenuText: I would think loose hair would suit you, Emanuele.
You look radiant, no matter the state of your hair, Emanuele.
I don't think you could look bad... even if you are a little disheveled at the moment.

Fields.DialogueText: R-Really, Capitano? Thank you. It's more practical and in keeping with my image to keep it up, but I'm flattered.
Hah, don't be silly, Capitano. I... I mean, grazie.
I'm not quite sure how to take that, Capitano.
Would you like to stay for a bit? I have some génépi here to share. I'm in the mood for some peace and quiet.
I'm afraid I'll have to decline your invitation, and ruin your peace and quiet too.
They're small, and swift. They were likely scouting ahead for that larger Morgana fleet.
Ah, clever Morganas. A bit of a hunt should wake me up, anyway. I'm sorry, pup, you'll have to go back into your kennel for now.
@BATTLE
We've received orders from the Protection Force officials in the New York Harbor to chase down Morganas who have been lurking around the coast.
New York Harbor is fascinating, Capitano. Look at all the ships! Look at all the people! I've never seen a city so varied.
Not even Rome, or Milan?
I have no memories of those places save what any average woman of Savoy would know of them, aside from their military significance.
You'll see many more cities like this in our travels, no doubt. But New York is something unique.
I can see that. ... You know, I would like to sail around the whole world with you, Capitano, if duty allowed it.
I didn't take your for the exploring type. You took leaving Italy so hard.
I love to explore. I just get melancholy when I leave home, because I fear whether I will ever come back.

Fields.MenuText: That's a reasonable fear, especially in a conflict like this.
No Morgana will sink you, if that's what you're worried about.
Keep yourself focused on the present. Don't worry about what might or might not happen.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes... It is. Even if I survive the war.
Your optimism is inspiring, Capitano. But sinking isn't all I'm worried about.
I'll heed your advice. Or, at least, I will try.
I sense some other Cattive Ragazze nearby. They may be heading for the harbor.
It's our duty to protect it, is it not?
Of course, Capitano.
@BATTLE
What are our orders, Capitano? I received the communication that we've been ordered to sail back to Italy.
That's a ruse, in case our communications are being intercepted by the Morganas.
I received our true orders in a meeting today with a representative of the Protection Force and an American naval officer.
What did they say?
We've been given a special task. Tonight, we will take on a cargo of contact mines. We've been tasked with laying a minefield off the coast to protect the harbor.
I see, Capitano. We're laying traps for our prey.
Exactly.
It strikes me that there is a possibility of civilian ships blundering into these minefields.
Anyone with clearance to enter or exit New York Harbor will be navigated through the minefield. The risk is minimal.
Are you sure?

Fields.MenuText: Of course. The fleet wouldn't take an action that would endanger so many civilian lives.
It's what is necessary to protect the harbor.
It's not our job to question orders.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope so. I'll trust your judgment.
I suppose it is. We will do our duty.
Though we must obey, it is our duty to at least think about the consequences of our orders!
It will be fine. Come on, I could use your help with preparing the ship. Unless you have something more pressing?
Of course not. I will glad to help, Capitano.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
How is the minelaying going, Emanuele?
Well enough, Capitano. The crew has adapted quickly to their new task.
How long do you think we will be able to keep this operation a secret?
Until the first Morgana blunders into it and gets away. That will happen eventually, but the fleet should be able to keep it quiet until then.
At least, our crew will be able to keep it quiet. I trust. I hope.
Do you trust our crew? I'm surprised.
I'm trying to, Capitano. I care for them. They've become a bit like family out here. I've never had such a family before.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you're coming to trust them.
I'm glad you care for them, but be cautious.
You shouldn't trust just because you want to.

Fields.DialogueText: It's because of you that it's become a bit easier to trust the crew.
Always. I'm always cautious.
I know! I've given this thought. I won't go around spilling any secrets, though, trust me.
I trust you, Capitano. Above all else.
I'm glad. We're done laying mines for now. The fleet reported Morganas to the south. If they wander up this direction, they could jeopardize our mission.
So we should hunt them down. Make it obvious we're in the area hunting, and not doing anything that might be seen as suspicious.
I like the way you think.
@BATTLE
Another group of Morganas was spotted near New York Harbor. What do you say we go and greet them?
@BATTLE
They certainly weren't prepared to deal with what they were hunting. Hmm. A common mistake, for hunters who don't heed their lessons.
Excellent manoeuvering, Emanuele. Both you and the crew did exceptionally well.
Grazie, Capitano. I agree - the crew outperformed themselves. Perhaps this calls for a celebration?

Fields.MenuText: An extra ration of alcohol for the crew at dinner, and license to have a bit of fun.
Hmm. Perhaps we can celebrate if you still have that génépi.
We're just doing our duties. What is there to celebrate there?

Fields.DialogueText: Sounds like a good idea, Capitano. I love a bit of celebration, as long as we keep alert.
Just you and me? That would be a bit unfair, I think. But I suppose it is the capitano and Belle's privilege.
I know, Capitano. But celebration is good for a crew, now and again.
Well, speaking of celebration, I do have a gift for you.
A gift? What is it? ... Capitano! Where...? How...? This is a book of Valdôtain poetry! By Angeline Curtaz!
You know her?
I know of her. She comes from the Valley of Aosta, like me. She's one of the few poets still publishing in Valdôtain in Italy. It's perilous in the current political climate, as you can imagine.
I bought the book in New York. I must have searched half the bookstores in the city, but I found you a book of poems in your language.
I... Capitano, I... I can't even... I can't believe you remembered. Thank you! Thank you so much!
What are you doing, Emanuele?
Ah... I was just up here trying to teach the pup a few commands. What's wrong, Capitano?
I saw you throwing something overboard.
I... was just getting rid of some old correspondence.
You've never sent a letter to my knowledge.
A crew member asked me to--
Throw their correspondence overboard? Stop lying...
Emanuele...

Fields.MenuText: You told me you trusted me. Tell me what you're doing.
I'm your captain. Tell me what you're doing.
Tell me what you're doing. That's an order.

Fields.DialogueText: I do trust you. Capitano, I...
I- I... Capitano... It's not anything... I'm not...
Yes, Capitano. I... well... I just...
Capitano, there are Morganas--
Don't try to change the subject!
Look, Capitano! On the horizon!
Fine. We'll talk about this later.
@BATTLE
Capitano. I'm sorry. I should have--
What were you doing?
I think my paranoia is starting to affect you.
Maybe it is. I wouldn't have suspected you of anything, but you talk incessantly of spies and informants, and then I find you throwing pieces of paper into the sea.

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps I'm overreacting, but humor me. Tell me what you were doing.
We're at war. There's no room for doubting loyalties.
I've heard a guilty conscience projects their own crimes onto others.

Fields.DialogueText: I can understand why you reacted that way. I'm sorry for causing so much fuss.
I understand. I know too that I must put you on edge, complaining about my own loyalties.
That's not true in my case. But I can understand your line of thinking. I'm sorry for causing a fuss.
The truth is, I was... trying my hand at writing some poetry. I had some grand idea about helping preserve my language.
And then I realized how irresponsible that was of me. To let other things occupy my time, to get caught up in that struggle when I should focus on the one happening in front of me.
I was afraid of letting you and the crew down. I was ashamed. So I ripped out the pages and threw the poetry into the sea.
That was all it was. I couldn't pass information off to someone else. I couldn't betray you, Capitano.
You mean you wouldn't.
No. I literally could not.
There's no time to talk about this now. I can sense Morganas nearby. They're... moving slowly. They may be damaged. Perhaps they're trying to escape an encounter with another ship.
We'll do our duty, then. I believe you, but this conversation isn't over, Emanuele.
@BATTLE
Captain, we are taking heavy fire.
I know, but d'Aosta can give as good as she gets.
@BATTLE
Look out, Capitano!
Woah! Thank you. I didn't see that bit of metal.
It must have broken off up above due to the shelling.
... If that thing had hit me, I would have been out of commission.
It worries me sometimes, Capitano, how fragile humans are. ... I wouldn't want to lose you.
You won't, hopefully.
Emanuele... what you said about not being able to betray me... were you speaking literally?
You're my capitano. I'm your Belle. Your goals are mine, your orders I take to heart. Betraying you would be a fundamental denial of what I am.
Whether I like what I am or not. No Belle would betray her capitano. Ever.
Glad that's settled.
You don't have to be ashamed of writing poetry, Emanuele. We all need distractions to keep ourselves sane.
I have no doubt you can write poetry and still be a capable Belle. Just don't act so secretive.
I won't, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe not you, but I've heard some Belles have had problems like that.
Why is this leap of faith so difficult?
I can see the truth in your eyes. I believe you.

Fields.DialogueText: Other Belles. Not me.
I've dealt with spies and traitors, so I understand how you feel.
Good.
I'm sure you can understand my position, then. It's not easy.
I do understand.
Where do you think the Fleet will send us next, now that the minefield is complete? Back to Europe?
Possibly. The Americas are having their share of struggles, but the Italian government has been vocal about wanting their Belles closer to home.
Not surprising, though if they insist on it too much, they may compromise the Protection Force's naval strategy.
Italy has complained that its lack of infrastructure to build and repair ships puts it at greater risk of loss than the rest of the countries providing resources to the Protection Force.
That is true, Capitano. Regardless of my feelings concerning the Italian government, losing me or one of my half-sisters would put a serious dent in Italy's naval power.

Fields.MenuText: It's sensible they are being cautious when they have something as precious as Belles to protect.
Every country is risking much in this fight. They don't have the right to complain so much.
They should be concerned about the fate of mankind, not just that of their own country.

Fields.DialogueText: We're not built to be protected. We're built to serve.
I agree. They should do their duty. It is a fact, though, that Italy does not have the capacity to rebuild ships if it loses them.
Everyone looks after their own first, Capitano. Regardless of what is right.
I suppose it is pointless to speculate now. We should leave that to our superiors, and focus on the tasks we've already been given.
We did receive information about Morgana sightings off the coast to the south of here.
Let's hunt, then, Capitano. We've wasted enough time talking.
@BATTLE
@BATTLE
d'Aosta? Ah, I see you're busy.
Ah, Capitano. No, I'm not really busy at all. I was just trying to teach the pup a thing or two. Come over and spend some time with me.
Heard about the course we were setting?
Of course. I'm excited. I've never been to New Orleans before, but I heard France had a large impact on its culture. Perhaps I will get an excuse to practice my French.
How do you speak French so well? Because Savoy is partially French?
Valdôtain has its origins in French as well as Italian, you know. In some ways, Savoy is just as much French as it is Italian.
... In other respects, it is neither French nor Italian.
That must be difficult in the present political atmosphere.
Hah. Yes. Mussolini and his party want to rid Italy of other cultures. He wants to take away our history, our language.
In his mind, Italian culture must be uniform, from the Alps all the way to Rome.
It's just... wrong. But we shouldn't speak of that, now. Would you care for some génépi?

Fields.MenuText: I would love some.
Perhaps another time. There's work to be done.
I prefer not to drink.

Fields.DialogueText: Here you go! The flavor might be a bit strong, but once you get used to it, you're likely to enjoy it.
Sensible. Some other time, maybe.
Oh! Of course. I respect that.
Did you know that I have a Croix de Guerre? The Italian government doesn't allow me to wear it, though.
They would rather I wear this ugly "Si" slogan of theirs, pinned to my jacket, instead of a French medal.
They would have preferred I get rid of the medal entirely, but they allowed me to keep it, on the condition I never wear it.
I'm sorry, Emanuele. Also, I've noticed you're being very free with your words right now.
Maybe the drink helped, but maybe it's just being around you. Stay with me for a bit longer, Capitano?
It's a bit lonely down here, sometimes. And I've been thinking too much about myself. Maybe you could tell me more about you.
We rarely talk about you!
I can probably come up with a few interesting anecdotes...
Another group of them, off the port beam. All hands to battle stations!
We're heading back to Italy for sure, from what I surmised from those communications.
We're running a convoy, escorting merchant ships carrying raw materials from America to Italy, to aid the Italians in the construction of new ships.
The Protection Force is trying to appease Italy, then, to keep my government from yanking us back like puppies on leashes.
That's no way to train a dog, is it, pup? Yanking him around cruelly?
We'll be in New Orleans soon. Do you want me to pick you up anything from the city?
Ah... a notebook, maybe? If that wouldn't be too much trouble. I was thinking of continuing my poetry. I promise I won't throw it overboard this time.
Good. It would be a waste of words. Aren't the words in your language especially precious?
Hah, maybe to me, Capitano.
It would be a waste of your talent, too.
Ah... You've never read any of my poetry, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: I don't have to. Your passion for your language is obvious, as is your talent with words.
If you write half as well as you shoot, you're better than most poets.
Then show some to me. Prove me wrong.

Fields.DialogueText: Hah, you flatter me...
I am a good shot, but that's no way to judge how good I am with a pen!
You don't speak Valdôtain. You couldn't read it.
I'm fully in support of your writing. Just don't let it distract you from your duties.
*ALARM*
It might take longer to reach New Orleans than I thought.
Let's get to it!
@BATTLE
Emanuele... I'm back!
What is it, Capitano? What's wrong? Did the meeting with the Protection Force brass go badly? Is Italy trying to take command of me away from you?

Fields.MenuText: I would never let that happen.
The Fleet would never let that happen.
Why is that always your primary worry?

Fields.DialogueText: Good. Don't let them surprise you when they try.
I'd like to believe that.
Because it's a possibility. I wouldn't put it past the Italian government.
No, no, nothing like that. The meeting went fine. We're set to help escort that convoy of merchant ships back to Italy.
Then what's wrong? I still sense bad news.
*ALARM*
That's not our alarm...
Cattive Ragazze must have been spotted close to the port!
Right. We'll talk later, then. Let's get going.
Tell me now, Capitano, if it's bad news. Quickly!
After the fight, Emanuele. I promise.
@BATTLE
So what's that bad news you've been saving for me? From your meeting, I mean.
I went to pick you up a notebook on the way back from the meeting with the fleet brass. I looked for some Italian newspapers, since you like reading those...
I do! Find any?
I found a place selling a few. They were a bit outdated, but I was skimming one, and I happened to recognize a name from one of the headlines. Take a look.
Writers being arrested in Italy for suspected sedition? ... And for anti-Italian ideas? ... Dreadful...
Oh! Angeline Curtaz. She's the poet from Savoy... They'll kill her. Her and all the others.

Fields.MenuText: I'm so sorry.

Fields.DialogueText: Emanuele?
Word came in while you were away. The port authorities want us to chase the Cattive Ragazze as far off as possible.
We will. Are you going to be all right? That newspaper article is pretty bad.
We should do our duty, Capitano.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Your country can be hard to love sometimes.
What can we do?

Fields.DialogueText: If I can think of something, you'll be the first to know.
You don't need to tell me...
Sit, Curtaz! Sit, boy!
The pup finally has a name?
A common name, in Savoy. Nobody would question me naming this pup that.
But that's not why you named him Curtaz, is it?
Names matter. We name things like bridges and streets and ships after certain people for a reason.
They name them after heroes, like my namesake. They name them because they want those people to be remembered.
I can't name anything as impressive as a bridge or ship. But my dog needed a name. I think it suits him, don't you?

Fields.MenuText: I do. It's a good name to remember.
It's a good name for a dog.
I think it's a bit risky.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you think so, Capitano.
Agreed.
Maybe, but it's a common last name in Savoy.
You should put Curtaz away in his kennel for now. I don't like the look of those ships on the horizon.
Nor do I. They look like Cattive Ragazze, looking to disrupt this convoy. Imagine what they could do with these materials.
We don't want to find out.
@BATTLE
I think you and Curtaz have the same expression on your faces.
Huh? What? Excuse me, Capitano, I'm not certain as to what you mean.
You both are looking hungrily at that bird up there. I know you're fond of hunting.
I was wishing for a rifle earlier... but one of the crew members caught me looking and said it would be bad luck to shoot down that bird. It's an albatross, you see.

Fields.MenuText: Probably best you didn't, then. It could bring bad luck.
It's good you listened. Sailors can be strangely superstitious.
You shouldn't have listened to those silly superstitions.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know about bad luck, but I know traditions should be respected.
Exactly. I didn't want any rumors of bad luck to spread.
Superstitions are like traditions. They should be respected. Especially if people take them seriously.
Fair enough. What do you think of traveling with the convoy?
A duty I've had before. I actually spent my first voyage travelling with my sister. And right now, well... I was hoping to speak with the other ships.
The other ships aren't Belles.
True. But I can sense their thoughts and feelings. In a way.
I wish they were Belles. Considering the number of Morganas we've been encountering, we could use the help.
Speak of the devil, and you see the horns coming... Cattive Ragazze off to starboard.
Targeting the merchant ships again.
I doubt they have much of a source of raw materials other than attacking convoys like this. We should ready the crew for a fight, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Emanuele? Emanuele! I heard you were down here. Emanuele!
Over here, Capitano.
Emanuele! ... You're looking... flushed. Had a few drinks?
... Maybe a little. I just... I was just thinking too much.
You know... it's funny. If you asked me... if you asked me if I wanted to be a Belle, I would probably say no.
I don't want to be a Belle. I don't want to be this... this thing, tied to metal and wood, sailing the sea until I sink.
Emanuele...?
But I've never had a choice. It's like the fascist elections in Italy. No opposing names, no choices, just a box to mark "Si" and an implicit threat if you do otherwise.
There's no choice to being a Belle.

Fields.MenuText: In reality, how many of us have free rein in our lives? We all follow orders.
You have free will. You've made choices.
You're worrying about this too much.

Fields.DialogueText: But I'm not even human, Capitano. I... care for you, and would never betray you, but... I don't even have the option to betray you. Or to end our friendship, like any human might.
Inconsequential choices. Choices that fall in line with the ship I was created to be.
I can hardly think about anything else right now, Capitano.
You've told me about at least one choice you've made. You chose me. You had no obligation, no prompting. You chose me to be your captain.
Our relationship is on equal footing. You chose me, and you can reject me if you want. If it is what you want, I could have you assigned to a different captain.
That's a choice you have. I don't want to force your loyalty, d'Aosta. I never have. We all have to follow orders, but in the end, I want your life to be in your own hands.
R-really?
Of course. Now, come on. I'll help you back to your quarters. Lean on me. Maybe you can get a little rest before more bad news arrives...
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
And yet, if I could make a choice, and I chose to be just an alpine girl... I might well be dead now, like Angeline Curtaz. Being a Belle keeps me further from that fate, I guess.
Is that what you want to do?
Maybe you're missing the point a bit.
*ALARM*
All hands, report to your battle stations.
@BATTLE
A few of those incoming shells were close calls, Capitano.
More difficult to fight Morganas when you're also trying to watch over ships with little ability to protect themselves.
The faster we get to Italy, the better.
Are you going to be all right, going back to Italy?
It's my home, Capitano. For better or for worse. I can't avoid that.
I've... been thinking about the conversation we had when I was drunk. Sometimes I resent being a Belle, it's true. But... also, I wouldn't be who I am now if I weren't a Belle.
I wouldn't know you, or have the family I have in the crew. And... I enjoy this life. I enjoy exploring with you.

Fields.MenuText: You had to work through it.
Glad you feel that way.
I'm surprised you remember that conversation at all.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you took the time to listen to me then. I know I wasn't being very coherent.
I'm glad you helped me realize it!
Drinking isn't as much of an inconvenience to me as it may be to you.
In case you were wondering... I have no intention of taking you up on your offer. I like having you as my capitano. I would never choose another to stand on my bridge.
But thank you for giving me the choice.
What have you been doing down here? I haven't seen you up on deck for hours.
I thought I would take advantage of the quiet day to get some writing done.
Poetry? You're using the notebook I bought you! How do you like it?
It's perfect. Thank you. It's been... liberating, I've found, to write everything down. I understand why so many people do it.
I'm afraid I haven't been as aware of the ship's communications as I am normally - have we received any new orders?

Fields.MenuText: Are you developing poor habits, Emanuele?
Understandable, Emanuele.
I thought you said you weren't going to neglect your duty on this ship.

Fields.DialogueText: No! It's not as easy as you think to focus on a hundred little details at one time, Capitano.
Even so, I'll try to stay more focused.
I won't! It's just... sometimes it's a bit much, with all the words buzzing through my head, when I'm trying to focus. I won't tune them out again.
Now that we're nearing Italy, your government wants us to break off from the convoy briefly and chase Morganas to the south.
Then we will return, make port with the convoy, and be received by envoys of the Italian government.
Lovely. Shall we deal with the greater of two evils first, then?
The Morganas, and then the envoys.
@BATTLE
How do I look, Capitano?
Stunning as always, Emanuele. Prepared to deal with the Italian envoys?
I want them on board as much as I want Cattive Ragazze astern... but I'm good at concealing my feelings, Capitano, so don't worry.

Fields.MenuText: I share that sentiment.
I'm not worried.
You might be easier to read than you realize.

Fields.DialogueText: We're in this together, at least. We can face them together.
Good. We're in this together. We can make polite conversation with them.
Ha! What's that supposed to mean? Not everybody can read me like you, Capitano.
They should have nothing but congratulations and gratitude for us, given that we delivered the convoy.
Knowing my government, no doubt they will have some words of criticism, for me at least. But we can deal with them.
Wait... Over there! Cattive Ragazze, for certain. I can practically smell them. Maybe we won't have to meet with those envoys, after all.
Our primary duty is to deal with Morganas!
Exactly. Take my hand, Capitano! We have to go ready the crew.
@BATTLE
A moment, Capitano? I have something I want to give to you.
Sure, Emanuele. What is it? ... What are these pages?
I've been writing... working hard to preserve my language in poetry. I can't publish anything while the war is on... but I wanted to entrust these poems to you.
When the war ends, and the enemy are finally defeated... perhaps they could be made into a book.
I want them to survive, even if... even if I sink. Will you keep them safe?
Of course.
Capitano, I've known for awhile that I have strong feelings for you. I won't keep that a secret from you any longer.
Well... So. How did your meeting with the envoys go?

Fields.MenuText: I knew it.
I thought you'd never say it.
Well, this is unexpected.

Fields.DialogueText: What? Really? I... That's embarrassing. I was trying to conceal it.
Ha! You knew? All this time?
I won't keep secrets from you.
I've known, but until recently I never quite expected to hear you say the words.
You don't have to reciprocate my feelings, but I had to express the truth instead of hiding it. Even if it's wrong to have feelings like this for you, it's right to admit it.
There. Did I get carried away just now? Maybe. But it's done!
Emanuele. You have nothing to worry about. I respect that courage.
Does my having feelings for you constitute some sort of neglect of my duties?
I hope not, because I have the same feelings for you, too.
Oh...
You're a complicated, challenging, inspiring person. And even when it was dangerous to speak the truth, you did it.
Emanuele... can you read me some of your poems? I'd like to hear them, even if I don't understand them.
Some of them are about you, Capitano. If you can't tell which ones, just watch to see if I blush when I read it.
Even if you never did, I would know. That would have been enough for me.
Before you start, show me what it looks like when you blush... so I know what to look for.
That's easy. Watch my face carefully for a moment... *kiss* That will probably do it!
One last push, Emanuele! Targets coming over the horizon.
@BATTLE
